data.title: Mouse.SetPosition not updating Mouse.GetState().Position on Mac

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I searched for a while regarding this issue and it seems that is has not been reported yet.
The Mouse.GetState() is only updated when the user moves the mouse himself.

Therefore, the output for this is the last position the user moved the mouse to, and not (0,0):
`Mouse.SetPosition(0, 0);
Console.WriteLine(Mouse.GetState().Position);`

I also tried with OpenTK.Input.Mouse, and same problem happens. It's a very big issue for FPS games where we want to reset the mouse position to the center of the game window at each loop.

Is there any alternatives for getting the mouse position on Mac?

data.title: MonoGame Pipeline tool on Windows uses the "Delete" word when it really means "Remove"

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
To reproduce:
1. Create a MonoGame Pipeline project
2. Save the MonoGame project in a folder
3. Create a new folder in Windows Explorer named "ToBeRemoved"
4. In the MonoGame Pipeline tool, add the newly-created ToBeRemoved folder
5. Right-click on the folder

Observe: The right-click menu includes a "Delete" folder, which Visual Studio users will understand to mean that the folder will both be removed from the MonoGame Pipeline project _and_ deleted from disk. 
Actual: The "Delete" menu item does not delete the folder from disk, it merely removes it from the MonoGame content project. The "Delete" word may make users nervous that the file will be deleted, and they may search for an alternative option to preserve the file on disk.

This menu item should be renamed to say "Remove" or "Exclude from Project" (to match the terminology of Visual Studio).

Note that Xamarin Studio uses the "Remove" word as well, and selecting this option then asks the user if the file should just be removed from the project or if it should also be deleted.

data.title: [DesktopGL / OpenTK / SDL2] GamePad crahes with some joystick
data.body:
Hello,

There is a bug in OpenTK SDL2 joystick driver (reported at opentk/opentk#377) which makes MonoGame to crash when some joystick are plugged. For instance, Saitek X55 (HOTAS joystick) is recognized as a gamepad but its value range are not compatible with a gamepad use and result in a crash when trying to `GamePad.GetState(int index)`.

data.title: Fixed thumbstick virtual buttons to always use independent axes.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Fixes #4741.

This PR changes how the thumbstick "virtual buttons" (e.g. `Buttons.LeftThumbstickUp`) are set so that it more closely matches XNA behaviour. Basically it now always uses the "independent axes" mode to determine the virtual buttons state regardless of the actual dead-zone mode being used.

data.title: Thumbstick virtual buttons don't always behave correctly

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I'm using the thumbstick "virtual buttons" (e.g. `Buttons.LeftThumbstickUp`) for navigation of my menu system when using a controller. I noticed that it was quite difficult to move up/down without accidentally also triggering left/right movement (and vice versa).

Looking into it further, I found it was because I was using a circular dead-zone mode. If I changed to the independent axes mode, then it was much less sensitive and easier to use. However, I need the circular dead-zone mode for player movement so this wasn't a practical solution.

When I compared this behaviour to XNA, I found that XNA seems to always use the independent axes mode when determining the "virtual buttons" state regardless of the dead-zone mode you specify. This would make sense as you need the independent axes mode to properly separate up/down from left/right movement.

So I believe the solution to this is to always use the independent axes mode when determining the thumbstick virtual buttons state. This should make MonoGame behave similarly to XNA in this respect. I'm currently working on a PR which does this and will submit it shortly.

data.title: Windows DX: Window is not centred on startup

data.body:
When using Windows DirectX, the game window is no longer centred on start up. Windows GL still works correctly.

Does anyone have any ideas on what might have broken this? If not, I will try take a look into this later when I have time.

data.title: Fixed back buffer MSAA on DirectX platforms.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
This PR adds some unit tests for `GraphicsDeviceManager` and fixes back buffer MSAA to work again under DirectX.

The MSAA stuff is not totally correct yet, but this is a good start.  We really need to refactor the graphics device creation so that we can query the MSAA support before creating the back buffer.  This will come in a future PR.

Also the unit test for checking if the back buffer MSAA is working is partially disabled under MonoGame.  This will be fixed after https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2382 is merged.

data.title: Xbox 360 GamePadCapabilities.GamePadType is Unknown on UWP
data.body:
Using a wired Xbox 360 for windows controller in a MonoGame UWP game, a call to 

`GamePadCapabilities capabilities = GamePad.GetCapabilities(PlayerIndex.One);`
`var g = capabilities.GamePadType; // GamePageType.Unknown`

returns an 'Unknown' GamepadType.

Using the MonoGame Windows project template the controller reports correctly as `Gamepad.Gamepad` using the exact same call.

I'm new to MonoGame so this could be intentional but it caught me out.

It should test that MSAA on the back buffer works as well as MSAA on render targets.

data.title: Make sure Pipeline tool starts even if Settings.XML is corrupted.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Looks like if the Settings.XML for the Pipeline GUI tool is screwed up the application silently fails to start.

 http://community.monogame.net/t/pipeline-exe-not-opening-resolved

We should protect against those cases and ensure the tool always starts no matter if the settings are corrupted or even if a command line option is incorrect.

data.title: Added CHANGELOG.md to project.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release

data.body:
This PR adds a CHANGELOG.md file to the repo populated with our old release information gathered from the website and other sources. I also hooked this into the documentation.

Please take a look and give me feedback on the formatting I've chosen for the change log:

  https://github.com/SickheadGames/MonoGame/blob/changelog/CHANGELOG.md

Am I missing anything, should I change anything in how we format this?

The next step will be integrating a tool to automatically generate the new release information using the information in PRs.

data.body: This PR marks Color.LerpPrecise as Obsolete as discussed in #4634

data.title: Support XNA GraphicsDevice Embedding
data.body:
Fix MonoGame to support the existing XNA style `GraphicsDevice` embedding as done in this tutorial:

 http://xbox.create.msdn.com/en-US/education/catalog/sample/winforms_series_1

First we need to be sure this works unchanged on Windows with DirectX.

Second we need to make it work under OpenGL on Windows with the simplest possible change to the technique.

Third we need to be sure the technique works on Mac and Linux which hopefully the fixes to support OpenGL make easier.

Once this is all in place we can investigate a method for embedding a `Game` expanding upon the techniques developed here.
